articles.headline: Alibaba’s American Aspirations
articles.snippet: The web giant is backing start-ups in Silicon Valley and introducing an online marketplace, 11 Main, aimed at U.S. shoppers and meant to compete with eBay.
articles.abstract: The web giant is backing start-ups in Silicon Valley and introducing an online marketplace, 11 Main, aimed at U.S. shoppers and meant to compete with eBay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Herb and Martha Oberman have made a good living on eBay for 17 years, selling paper collectibles like a $5,000 limited-edition menu from the Hotel Bel-Air, the Los Angeles hotel once frequented by Marilyn Monroe.
articles.byline: By David Gelles, Hiroko Tabuchi and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Norman Rockwell’s Art, Once Sniffed At, Is Becoming Prized
articles.snippet: Rockwell is poised to join a handful of artists whose work is recognizable not just for its artistic quality but for the millions it took to acquire one.
articles.abstract: Rockwell is poised to join a handful of artists whose work is recognizable not just for its artistic quality but for the millions it took to acquire one.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Rockwell’s greatest sin as an artist is simple: His is an art of unending cliché.”

articles.headline: Others Fade, but Judge Judy Is Forever: At 71, She Still Presides
articles.snippet: Judge Judith Sheindlin just had a prime-time special and her flagship program has been renewed for three more seasons.
articles.abstract: Judge Judith Sheindlin just had a prime-time special and her flagship program has been renewed for three more seasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Judge Judith Sheindlin, the straight-talking star of “Judge Judy,” peered down at a sassy defendant with disgust. “Listen to me, Miss Fibby,” Judge Sheindlin snapped at a recent taping here. “They don’t keep me here because I’m gorgeous. They keep me here because I’m smart.”

articles.headline: G.O.P.’s Foreign Policy Hawks Wary of Paul’s Evolving Views
articles.snippet: As Senator Rand Paul considers a potential run for president in 2016, powerful voices of the Republican base have undertaken a campaign to portray his stance on foreign affairs as dangerously misguided.
articles.abstract: As Senator Rand Paul considers a potential run for president in 2016, powerful voices of the Republican base have undertaken a campaign to portray his stance on foreign affairs as dangerously misguided.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rand Paul had just finished his opening remarks at a private gathering of Republican power brokers at the Four Seasons in Georgetown last fall when Phil Gramm, the former senator from Texas, shot up his hand with the first question.

articles.headline: Nigeria’s Army Hampers Hunt for Abducted Schoolgirls
articles.snippet: Foreign diplomats say the army is so poorly trained and riddled with corruption that it is losing the fight against Boko Haram.
articles.abstract: Foreign diplomats say the army is so poorly trained and riddled with corruption that it is losing the fight against Boko Haram.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — Intelligence agents from all over the globe have poured into this city, Nigeria’s capital, to help find the nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls abducted by the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram more than a month ago — but there has been little or no progress in bringing the young women home.

articles.headline: Video Rant, Then Deadly Rampage in California Town
articles.snippet: A college student who documented his rage against women for rejecting him killed six people and wounded 13 others during a spasm of terror on Friday night.
articles.abstract: A college student who documented his rage against women for rejecting him killed six people and wounded 13 others during a spasm of terror on Friday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — A college student who posted videos that documented his rage against women for rejecting him killed six people and wounded 13 others during a spasm of terror on Friday night, the police said. He stabbed three men to death in his apartment and shot the others as he methodically opened fire on bystanders on the crowded streets of this small town.
articles.byline: By Ian Lovett and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: The Deal’s Done. But Not the Fees.
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission is taking a closer look at what private equity firms charge their investors.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is taking a closer look at what private equity firms charge their investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was joy on Park Avenue as the news arrived from Warsaw, a small Indiana city.

articles.headline: When Cannabis Goes Corporate
articles.snippet: With a sweeping new policy for medical marijuana, Canada is aiming for a market of large-scale — and highly regulated — growers.
articles.abstract: With a sweeping new policy for medical marijuana, Canada is aiming for a market of large-scale — and highly regulated — growers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hershey stopped producing chocolate in Smiths Falls, Ontario, six years ago. The work went to Mexico, but the factory remains, along with reminders of the glory days: A sign that once directed school buses delivering children for tours. A fading, theme-park-style entrance that marks what used to be the big attraction — a “Chocolate Shoppe” that sold about $4 million of broken candy and bulk bars a year.

articles.headline: Final Word on U.S. Law Isn’t: Supreme Court Keeps Editing
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, a secretive process that has led judges, lawyers and scholars astray.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, a secretive process that has led judges, lawyers and scholars astray.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, altering the law of the land without public notice. The revisions include “truly substantive changes in factual statements and legal reasoning,” said Richard J. Lazarus, a law professor at Harvard and the author of a new study examining the phenomenon.

articles.headline: Egypt’s New Strongman, Sisi Knows Best
articles.snippet: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s cunning path to power and his paternalistic conviction that the people must be prepared to suffer are illuminated in interviews and leaked recordings.
articles.abstract: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s cunning path to power and his paternalistic conviction that the people must be prepared to suffer are illuminated in interviews and leaked recordings.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army officer soon to be Egypt’s president, promises to remedy Egypt’s crippling fuel shortage by installing energy-efficient bulbs in every home socket, even if he has to send a government employee to screw in each one.

articles.headline: For Crimea, It’s Russian Troops In, Tourists Out
articles.snippet: With its economy flatlining, Crimea desperately needs a banner year in tourism. But with the violent portrait Russian television has painted of Ukraine, few seem likely to come.
articles.abstract: With its economy flatlining, Crimea desperately needs a banner year in tourism. But with the violent portrait Russian television has painted of Ukraine, few seem likely to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: YALTA, Crimea — When choosing the idyllic setting for an extramarital affair, Anton Chekhov opted for Yalta, and this seaside resort proved so grateful that it erected a bronze statue of the fictional enchantress with her Pomeranian on the main boardwalk.

articles.headline: Using Jailed Migrants as a Pool of Cheap Labor
articles.snippet: As the federal government cracks down on immigrants in the country illegally and forbids businesses to hire them, it is relying on tens of thousands of those immigrants each year to provide essential labor.
articles.abstract: As the federal government cracks down on immigrants in the country illegally and forbids businesses to hire them, it is relying on tens of thousands of those immigrants each year to provide essential labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The kitchen of the detention center here was bustling as a dozen immigrants boiled beans and grilled hot dogs, preparing lunch for about 900 other detainees. Elsewhere, guards stood sentry and managers took head counts, but the detainees were doing most of the work — mopping bathroom stalls, folding linens, stocking commissary shelves.

articles.headline: Pope, in Mideast, Invites Leaders to Meet on Peace
articles.snippet: Wading into the heart of Middle East tensions, Pope Francis also endorsed “the State of Palestine” in symbolic visits to the West Bank and Jerusalem.
articles.abstract: Wading into the heart of Middle East tensions, Pope Francis also endorsed “the State of Palestine” in symbolic visits to the West Bank and Jerusalem.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Pope Francis inserted himself directly into the collapsed Middle East peace process on Sunday, issuing an invitation to host the Israeli and Palestinian presidents for a prayer summit meeting at his apartment in the Vatican, in an overture that has again underscored the broad ambitions of his papacy.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren, Jim Yardley and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Pro-European Businessman Claims Victory in Ukraine Presidential Vote
articles.snippet: As voters cast their ballots to replace their toppled president, surveys showed the pro-Western billionaire Petro Poroshenko holding a wide lead over his strongest rival.
articles.abstract: As voters cast their ballots to replace their toppled president, surveys showed the pro-Western billionaire Petro Poroshenko holding a wide lead over his strongest rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Caught in a battle for influence between Russia and the West, Ukrainians elected Petro O. Poroshenko as president on Sunday, turning to a pro-European billionaire to lead them out of six months of turmoil.

articles.headline: No Time to Text? Say It With Stickers
articles.snippet: Sticker-based apps like Line and WeChat have transformed mobile messaging in Asia, but they have been slow to catch on in North America.
articles.abstract: Sticker-based apps like Line and WeChat have transformed mobile messaging in Asia, but they have been slow to catch on in North America.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the messaging app Line, a late-afternoon conversation between colleagues might involve a series of colorful icons, or stickers — a way to invite someone out for a drink or to gently say no:

articles.headline: Hospitals Look to Health Law, Cutting Charity
articles.snippet: Some systems have started scaling back financial assistance for lower- and middle-income people without health insurance, hoping to push them to sign up for coverage through online marketplaces.
articles.abstract: Some systems have started scaling back financial assistance for lower- and middle-income people without health insurance, hoping to push them to sign up for coverage through online marketplaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hospital systems around the country have started scaling back financial assistance for lower- and middle-income people without health insurance, hoping to push them into signing up for coverage through the new online marketplaces created under the Affordable Care Act.

articles.headline: A Platform and Blogging Tool, Medium Charms Writers
articles.snippet: Better content production tools often lead to better content, and Medium, a blogging platform, is simple and intuitive.
articles.abstract: Better content production tools often lead to better content, and Medium, a blogging platform, is simple and intuitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Evan Williams is at it again. Mr. Williams is sitting in an office here a mile up the road from Twitter, where he is a founder and is still a board member, working on Medium, an amorphous-sounding company that could be one more curio of the Internet age or might end up taking over the world.

articles.headline: Political Ad Man Finds the Personal in Democratic Hopefuls
articles.snippet: As the electoral season heats up, the abilities of Mark Putnam are in hot demand in the Democratic Party, especially among candidates running in red states.
articles.abstract: As the electoral season heats up, the abilities of Mark Putnam are in hot demand in the Democratic Party, especially among candidates running in red states.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —  Mark Putnam has convinced a Democratic political candidate to swim the Hudson River in February (Mayor Steven Fulop of Jersey City). He has cajoled one to sling luggage on the tarmac at the Baltimore-Washington airport (Senator Ben Cardin of Maryland). And more recently, he persuaded another to ride a snowmobile in subzero temperatures (Senator Mark Begich of Alaska).

articles.headline: Parents’ Nightmare: Futile Race to Stop Killings
articles.snippet: After Elliot O. Rodger declared his plans for “retribution,” his parents made one last, frantic effort to thwart him.
articles.abstract: After Elliot O. Rodger declared his plans for “retribution,” his parents made one last, frantic effort to thwart him.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was Friday evening when the parents of Elliot O. Rodger clicked open the 140-page manifesto emailed to them from their son and learned of his plans for mass murder and suicide. Frightened and alarmed, they called 911 and then raced to Isla Vista, Calif., in separate cars from Los Angeles, desperate to stop him.

articles.headline: Insurers Once on the Fence Plan to Join Health Exchanges in ’15
articles.snippet: Several carriers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will join the exchanges or expand their offerings to more states.
articles.abstract: Several carriers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will join the exchanges or expand their offerings to more states.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign of the growing potential under the federal health care law, several insurers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will sell policies on the new exchanges in the coming year, and others plan to expand their offerings to more states.

articles.headline: Global Digital News Brands See Growth Opportunity in India
articles.snippet: BuzzFeed, Huffington Post and Atlantic Media are among the companies with plans to build major online news operations in India, both on their own and with local partners.
articles.abstract: BuzzFeed, Huffington Post and Atlantic Media are among the companies with plans to build major online news operations in India, both on their own and with local partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newspaper is everywhere in India. Print readership, especially of the country’s vernacular press, is continuing to rise.

articles.headline: Colleges Rattled as Obama Seeks Rating System
articles.snippet: College presidents are balking at President Obama’s call for a rating system that would compare schools to aid prospective students and determine federal funding.
articles.abstract: College presidents are balking at President Obama’s call for a rating system that would compare schools to aid prospective students and determine federal funding.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The college presidents were appalled. Not only had President Obama called for a government rating system for their schools, but now one of his top education officials was actually suggesting it would be as easy as evaluating a kitchen appliance.

articles.headline: Populists’ Rise in Europe Vote Shakes Leaders
articles.snippet: In France, Britain and elsewhere, voters turned against traditional parties to support anti-immigrant groups opposed to the European Union.
articles.abstract: In France, Britain and elsewhere, voters turned against traditional parties to support anti-immigrant groups opposed to the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An angry eruption of populist insurgency in the elections for the European Parliament rippled across the Continent on Monday, unnerving the political establishment and calling into question the very institutions and assumptions at the heart of Europe’s post-World War II order.

articles.headline: Pfizer Abandons Bid for AstraZeneca
articles.snippet: Pfizer said it “does not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca” in the wake of AstraZeneca’s rejection of a $119 billion bid.
articles.abstract: Pfizer said it “does not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca” in the wake of AstraZeneca’s rejection of a $119 billion bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:36 p.m. | On the final day for Pfizer to decide whether to abandon the plan, it said it did not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca. Last week, the British company rejected what Pfizer had called its final offer. The cash-and-stock bid, which valued AstraZeneca at about $119 billion, would have created the world’s largest drug company.
